August 31 at 2:21 PM ·

Tickets go on sale this week for Heritage's 'TRUTH OR MYTH?' GUIDED WALKING TOUR in downtown Lancaster, Ohio!

Our town has produced many great stories, but are they true? Find out Oct. 23 by joining one of our 90-minute guided walking tours.

Hear stories of a ghostly specter on a widow’s walk, William Tecumseh Sherman’s Confederate ex- girlfriend, a bank robbery during the Depression, Civil War stories from a soldier, and tales of early Lancaster and some of its ne’er-do-wells.

Each tour begins at the Georgian, 105 E. Wheeling Street, Lancaster, and are limited to 15 for each time slot: 6pm, 6:30pm, 7pm, 7:30pm, and 8pm.

Tickets go on sale Sept. 1 to members of the Fairfield County Heritage Association.

Tickets go on sale to the public on Sept. 2. Cost will be $15 per person. Call 740-654-9923 or order online at www.FairfieldHeritage.com.

Don’t myth it!

Mr. John Edward “Jack” Brown served the district as Superintendent from 1954 to 1968. He was a New Straitsville native and Ohio University graduate. During Mr. Brown’s superintendency, the district’s enrollment jumped from 5,100 students to 8,300 students. To accommodate Lancaster’s growing population, he devoted a great part of his energy toward an extensive building program. The story is told of Jack…

On behalf of the Fairfield County Sheriff's Office:
(Yes, it's that time again - everybody's favorite post)
With kids starting back to school, do you know when to stop for a school bus? (THIS IS FOR OHIO-EACH STATE MAY DIFFER)
Straight from the Ohio's Drivers Handbook -
If the bus is stopped on a street or road which has fewer than four lanes, all traffic approaching the bus from either direction must stop at least 10 feet from the front or rear of the bus and remain stopped until the bus begins to move or the bus driver signals motorists to proceed.
* If the bus is stopped on a street or road which has four or more lanes, only traffic proceeding in the same direction as the bus must stop.

Do you have a bunch of CD cases at home? If so, make them into a mini greenhouse! This is a great experiment to do with kids.
1. Use a old CD case and fill it up halfway with compost/dirt.
2. Place a few seeds in the case and close the case.
3.Tape (clear packaging tape works best) the bottom of the CD case closed. This will help keep water from leaking if you overwatered.
4. Lightly water your seeds and place them in a window. *note: a few drops goes a long way!
5. Optional: Using a piece of tape or address label, write the date and what you planted.
You can continue to reuse the CD greenhouse for multiple seedlings.
Post photos below of your DIY CD Greenhouse!
